meanings.definition: To become accustomed to something unpleasant or difficult.
meanings.sent1: After a while, she began to inure herself to the cold weather.
meanings.sent2: Over time, people can inure themselves to the noise of the city.
meanings.sent3: He tried to inure himself to eating broccoli by pretending it was candy.
meanings.sent4: The challenges of the mountain climb helped inure her to physical exertion.
meanings.sent5: The soldiers had to inure themselves to the harsh conditions of the battlefield.

meanings.definition: To cause someone to become accustomed to something unpleasant or difficult.
meanings.sent1: The tough training regimen will inure the recruits to long hours of work.
meanings.sent2: Parents sometimes inadvertently inure their children to the stress of academic pressure.
meanings.sent3: The prank was meant to inure him to unexpected surprises.
meanings.sent4: The strict teacher's discipline methods inured the students to strict rules.
meanings.sent5: The constant exposure to loud music inured her to noise pollution.
